Title.evidence: Randomised Controlled Trial of Radiopaque Tissue Transfer System in Breast-Conserving Surgery

Trial_Design.evidence: The sample size was calculated to detect a 50% reduction in PMR with 80% power at a two-sided α level of 0.05.

Participants.evidence: 122 patients with microcalcification-associated breast cancer were randomised 1:1 to receive either KliniTray™ or the institutional standard orientation (ISO) procedure.

Intervention.evidence: 122 patients with microcalcification-associated breast cancer were randomised 1:1 to receive either KliniTray™ or the institutional standard orientation (ISO) procedure.

Objective.evidence: This randomised controlled trial assessed whether a radiopaque tissue transfer and X-ray system (KliniTray™) could reduce the positive margin rate (PMR) in breast-conserving surgery (BCS) for non-palpable breast cancer associated with microcalcifications.

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was the PMR, measured using final histopathology.

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Randomisation was performed using permutated block randomisation with allocation concealment via closed envelopes.

Blinding.evidence: The study was open-label, with no blinding of outcome assessors, patients, or clinicians.

Number_Randomised.evidence: Conducted at a single centre, 122 patients with microcalcification-associated breast cancer were randomised 1:1 to receive either KliniTray™ or the institutional standard orientation (ISO) procedure.

Number_Analysed.evidence: Of the 122 randomised, 117 patients were analysed (60 in the KliniTray™ group and 57 in the ISO group) using an intention-to-treat approach.

Result_Outcome.evidence: The final PMR was 31.7% for KliniTray™ and 26.3% for ISO (P = 0.127). Independent factors for positive margins included histological tumour size >30 mm (adjusted OR 10.73; 95% CI 3.14 to 36.75; P < 0.001) and specimen size >50 mm (adjusted OR 6.65; 95% CI 2.00 to 22.08; P = 0.002).
